Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Full-Scale Simulation of Peak Responses to Reduce Hurricane Damage to Low Buildings and Use of Related Research to Develop Hurricane-Engineering Expertise

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of this Faculty Early Career Development (CAREER) Program award is to ascertain the effects of roof shapes and coverings on uplift pressures and the dynamic response of flexible roofing systems subjected to hurricane winds. This objective will be accomplished through full-scale testing in the 12-fan Wall of Wind (WoW) simulation laboratory at Florida International University. The educational objective is to increase the number of undergraduate students in hurricane engineering academic programs. The project aims are to: (1) determine the extent to which full-scale testing can improve roof peak pressure estimates by simulating local flow fields near critical components; (2) determine through full-scale testing the dynamic response of flexible roofing systems subjected to high winds; and (3) synergistically integrate low building aerodynamics research with inductive learning to foster improvement in undergraduate student knowledge in hurricane engineering. The expected contributions include: (1) new load modification functions to improve peak estimates in existing aerodynamic database; (2) new knowledge on progressive load distribution among roof subassemblies before damage initiation and as damage propagates; and (3) new strategic framework for educating and influencing the career path of undergraduate and graduate students.

The research is expected to benefit the society as it has the potential of significantly improving building codes and standards to enhance the resiliency of low buildings that are vulnerable to damage in hurricane winds. These changes in building codes and standards will improve construction practices of low buildings and reduce damages in hurricane storms. Advancement of discovery will be incorporated in to education through step-by-step integration of new knowledge with inductive learning. Broadening participation of underrepresented groups will be fostered through active recruitment from minority serving institutions for this fascinating subject area. The educational contribution of this project will be significant by increasing number of students pursuing a career path of hurricane-qualified engineers. Research and education infrastructure will be enhanced through demonstration of valuable use of the 12-fan WoW facility and inductive learning modules transportable to wind/hurricane engineering curriculum around the globe. Outreach activities will be broadly pursued through presentations at various forums and publications.

POR.DRECONTENT:
High growth in hurricane-induced losses, from $1.3B/year prior to 1990 to $36B/year post-2000, is a major concern for U.S. coastal communities. Non-engineered low-rise buildings, including residential, institutional, and commercial structures, are the dominant building type in the U.S., and are among the most vulnerable under high winds. Post-disaster surveys have provided direct evidence that hurricane-induced damage and property losses are due in large part to failure of roofs and water intrusion. Wind tunnel testing on small-scale building models has so far provided the bulk of wind load estimates on which building code provisions are based. Such estimates are mostly accurate except for peak negative pressures (suctions) in critical regions where damage is often initiated. The CAREER project aimed to create a new methodology to facilitate large- and full-scale wind tunnel testing that is preferred for low-rise buildings structures and building appurtenances for maintaining modeling accuracy and minimizing scaling errors. The new methodology was used to obtain wind-induced peak pressures on several types of roofing systems including tiled roofs, roof pavers, standing seam metal roofing, and flexible roofing. The key outcome was the advancement of knowledge on surface flow mean wind speeds and net pressures on roofing systems. It was found that existing modeling techniques can underestimate wind loading in the ridge, hip and perimeter regions of roofs. Alternative modeling techniques were developed to improve upon the accuracy of estimated aerodynamic loading on roof elements. The expected outcome of these findings is better wind load design provisions. This will significantly reduce risk of failures that have been observed even in hurricanes with speeds well below the design wind speed.

The implications of the loss of roofing elements go well beyond the cost of roof replacement and include increased vulnerability to rainwater ingress and the possibility of windborne debris that threatens neighboring structures. The new data can improve the aerodynamic load provisions and improve the design of roofing components. The results of this project are being used to help develop design guidelines. Thus the findings are significant with regard to loss modeling, installation practice, wind-load standards, wind-speed assessment based on observed damage and mitigation policy. Based on the information gathered, guidelines suitable for codes and standards were developed for the design of roof pavers. The provisions are being proposed for inclusion in ASCE 7-22 Standard. The project served the national interest as the new design provisions can help develop hurricane-resilient communities, thus contributing to greater economic competitiveness of the U.S. coastal region.

The educational outcome is an increased pool of diverse students pursuing studies related to becoming hurricane-qualified engineers. New pedagogical methods were used to challenge students with hurricane problems integrated in a new course under FIU’s Global Learning for Global Citizenship initiative. Inquiry learning modules required students to answer complex real world questions based on the research results. Results of surveys indicated that students experienced significantly positive increases in their cognitive knowledge and global citizenship due to their global learning experiences in the classroom. The expected contribution of the educational activities is a new strategic framework for educating and influencing the career path of undergraduate students. The contribution will be significant because increased numbers of undergraduates will elect a career path that is relevant to becoming hurricane-qualified engineers.
